abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of the project was
            satisfactory. Most of its physical, financial, and
            institutional objectives were met, with a highly
            satisfactory rate of return. Sustainability of the power
            sector components is likely, while that of the coal sector
            components, depend on bridge financing, and sector
            restructuring, to be provided under a future operation. The
            key lessons suggest that even under early post-war
            conditions, revenue collection rates may be raised, almost
            near normal levels, as indicated by Elektroprivreda Bosnia
            and Herzegovina's (EPBiH) experience. However, project
            co-financing, consisting of a small number of co-financiers
            or parallel financiers, with firm commitments made prior to
            the Board presentation, would have proved a better
            financing, in contrast to the financing gaps, and, project
            alterations during implementation, thus resulting in a
            difficult, and, time consuming accounting operation.
            Although the Project Start-Up Advance facilitated
            procurement prior to Board approval, some difficulties among
            inter-agency transfers and adjustments did occur. Therefore,
            since advance funding under emergency projects is vital, a
            better consideration would be the use of enlarged Project
            Preparation Facilities, to avoid inter-agency difficulties.
            Project effectiveness was partly due to a strong Project
            Implementation Unit, who provided adequate coordination
            during implementation.
